On Fri, 30 Jan 2004, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:

> If tests are to be documentation about how to use the code being tested,
> then tests should only use only public methods/interfaces.

Ought that not read, "if tests are ONLY to be documentation...." But
surely the tests have other purposes as well. Such as...testing,
perhaps?

> Also, if tests depend on non-public parts of production classes, then
> the tests "get in the way" of refactorings that /should/ not affect
> client code.

So you just refactor the tests as well. It's no big deal.

> The whole point (!!) of the protected and private keyword is to shield
> client code from the inner-workings and details of design.

Indeed.

> Tests are client code.

No, they are tests. Sometimes they might act like client code.

> Why should tests get special access to these inner workings?

So that they can test these inner workings?

cjs
